text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s a reasonable ---- Family Member: But it wouldn’t stay down if things weren’t okay --- if you were getting worse, either. I mean, is there a false – Doctor: I mean, occasionally we have a patient where all the disease is getting better, and then one spot starts to grow. That’s where, that would be the one place we kind of fall through the cracks. But, usually, - the PSA represents the sum of all of the cancers in your body are contributing to it. So, usually, when it’s going down, we sort of think that the sum is going down. And, when it’s going up, we think that it’s starting to be resistant. Um. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: But it’s an indication of prostate cancer, and as far as we know, that’s all that he has. Doctor: Right. Right. Family Member: Even though, it’s in different places. Doctor: Right. And, sometimes when the PSA goes up, the scans can still look stable, because they’re not as sensitive to changes as the, as the – Patient: As the chemical – Doctor: Blood count. Yeah.

text: Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum.

Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. Doctor: And they confirmed that it’s prostate cancer. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, rather than liver cancer, yes, and that’s kind of where we stand. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You have Provenge. Um, so um, the one standard thing that’s left is a radiation-based thing but that’s really only for disease of the bone. You have lymph node as well. So I would sort of not use that. The other thing that’s left is chemotherapy, flavors, uh so that’s something we could always go to. The other sort of unfortunately gray zone (beeping) Patient: Sure. Doctor: Uh and some of that’s clinical trial. A lot of the clinical trials we have right now are hormonal based. So it’s Zytiga plus something, Xtandi plus something. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Versus something. So unfortunately uh you wouldn’t fit all those trials because of the prior treatments we have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign.

text: Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles) Doctor: No, no, I think the hair loss is all pretty much even after one or two, so after we stop the hair grows back. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So, so, that does happen. The other thing to watch for is if there’s tingling or numbness, okay, typically in the fingertips and the toes. If that is happening, I will, you know we may have to make adjustments to the dose. What happens is we start everyone on one standard dose and then dial down, depending on how they’re tolerated. Okay, so, so I think like I told you, the first course pretty much is important because both you and I will find out how you’re going to tolerate. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
